â
'''Google, Inc.''' {{nasdaq|GOOG}}, is a [[United States|U.S.]]-based corporation, established in [[1998]], that manages the [[Google search]] engine. Google is headquartered at the "[[Googleplex]]" in [[Mountain View, Santa Clara County, California|Mountain View]], [[California]], and employs over 3,000 workers. [[Eric Schmidt|Dr. Eric Schmidt]] became Google's [[CEO]] (he was previously the CEO of [[Novell]]) when co-founder [[Lawrence E. Page|Larry Page]] stepped down.
+
'''Google, Inc.''' {{nasdaq|GOOG}}, is a [[United States|U.S.]]-based corporation, established in [[1998]], that manages the [[Google search]] engine. Google is headquartered at the "[[Googleplex]]" in [[Mountain View, Santa Clara County, California|Mountain View]], [[California]], and employs over 1,000 workers. Google's [[CEO]] [[Eric Schmidt|Dr. Eric Schmidt]], formerly CEO of [[Novell]], took over when co-founder [[Lawrence E. Page|Larry Page]] stepped down.
==History==
==History==
===Beginnings===
===Beginnings===
â
Google began as a research project in early [[1996]] by [[Larry E. Page]] and [[Sergey Brin]], two [[Stanford University|Stanford]] [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] students who developed the theory that a search engine based on analysis of the relationships between Web sites would produce better results than the basic techniques then in use. It was originally nicknamed ''BackRub'' because the system checked [[backlinks]] to estimate a site's importance.
+
Google began as a research project in early [[1996]] by Larry Page and [[Sergey Brin]], two [[Stanford University|Stanford]] [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] students who developed the theory that a search engine based on analysis of the relationships between Web sites would produce better results than the basic techniques then in use. It was originally nicknamed ''BackRub'' because the system checked [[backlinks]] to estimate a site's importance.
Convinced that the pages with the most links to them from other highly relevant Web pages must be the most relevant ones, Page and Brin decided to test their thesis as part of their studies, and laid the foundation for their search engine. They formally founded their company, ''Google, Inc.'', on [[September 7]], [[1998]] at a friend's garage in [[Menlo Park, California|Menlo Park]], California. In February [[1999]], the company moved into offices at [[165 University Avenue]] in [[Palo Alto]], home of a number of other noted [[Silicon Valley]] technology startups. Google quickly outgrew the University Avenue site, moving to a complex of buildings (known by some as "The Googleplex") in [[Mountain View, Santa Clara County, California|Mountain View]]'s Amphitheater Parkway later that year.
Convinced that the pages with the most links to them from other highly relevant Web pages must be the most relevant ones, Page and Brin decided to test their thesis as part of their studies, and laid the foundation for their search engine. They formally founded their company, ''Google, Inc.'', on [[September 7]], [[1998]] at a friend's garage in [[Menlo Park, California|Menlo Park]], California. In February [[1999]], the company moved into offices at [[165 University Avenue]] in [[Palo Alto]], home of a number of other noted [[Silicon Valley]] technology startups. Google quickly outgrew the University Avenue site, moving to a complex of buildings (known by some as "The Googleplex") in [[Mountain View, Santa Clara County, California|Mountain View]]'s Amphitheater Parkway later that year.
â
The Google search engine gained a following among [[Internet]] users for its simple, clean design and relevant search results. [[Advertisement]]s were sold by the [[keyword]] so that they would be more relevant to the end user, and the ads were text-based in order to keep page design uncluttered and fast-loading. The concept of selling Keyword advertising was originally pioneered by [[Overture]][http://www.content.overture.com/d/USm/about/news/mile.jhtml], formerly Goto.com. While many of its [[dot-com]] siblings went under, Google quietly rose in stature while turning a profit.
+
The Google search engine gained a following among [[Internet]] users for its simple, clean design and relevant search results. In [[2000]], Google had begun selling [[advertisement]]s by the [[keyword]] so that they would be more relevant to the end user. The ads were text-based in order to keep page design uncluttered and fast-loading. The concept of selling keyword advertising was originally pioneered by [[Overture]][http://www.content.overture.com/d/USm/about/news/mile.jhtml], formerly Goto.com. While many of its [[dot-com]] siblings went under, Google quietly rose in stature while turning a profit.
In September [[2001]], Google's ranking mechanism ([[PageRank]]) was awarded a U.S. Patent. The patent was officially awarded to Leland Stanford University and lists Lawrence Page as the inventor. [http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO2&Sect2=HITOFF&p=1&u=/netahtml/search-bool.html&r=1&f=G&l=50&co1=AND&d=ptxt&s1=6,285,999.WKU.&OS=PN/6,285,999&RS=PN/6,285,999]
In September [[2001]], Google's ranking mechanism ([[PageRank]]) was awarded a U.S. Patent. The patent was officially awarded to Leland Stanford University and lists Lawrence Page as the inventor. [http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO2&Sect2=HITOFF&p=1&u=/netahtml/search-bool.html&r=1&f=G&l=50&co1=AND&d=ptxt&s1=6,285,999.WKU.&OS=PN/6,285,999&RS=PN/6,285,999]

â
The basic salaries at Google are considered low by some. For instance, [[system administrator]]s earn no more than $33,000-37,000, which some argue to be pretty low especially by [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]] standards.
+
The basic salaries at Google are considered low by some. For instance, [[system administrator]] earn no more than $33,000-37,000, which some argue to be pretty low especially by [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]] standards.

Line 80: Line 80:
===IPO and culture===
===IPO and culture===
â
Many people have suggested that after Google's IPO their culture will not be able to stay so "fun" and focused on the future.[http://www.wired.com/news/business/0,1367,63241,00.html?tw=wn_story_related] [http://www.ciol.com/content/news/2004/104043001.asp] The company may be required to answer to shareholders who will want the company to cut back on employee benefits and to focus on short term advances. Also, it may be hard to maintain a collegial atmosphere when approxiamtely 1,000 (30%) of the employees are paper-millionaires. In a report given to potential investors, co-founders [[Sergey Brin]] and [[Larry E. Page]] promised that the IPO would not change the company's culture. Later Mr. Page said, "We think a lot about how to maintain our culture and the fun elements."
+
Many people have suggested that after Google's IPO their culture will not be able to stay so "fun" and focused on the future.[http://www.wired.com/news/business/0,1367,63241,00.html?tw=wn_story_related] [http://www.ciol.com/content/news/2004/104043001.asp] The company may be required to answer to shareholders who will want the company to cut back on employee benefits and to focus on short term advances. Also, it may be hard to maintain a collegial atmosphere when some of the employees are paper-millionaires. In a report given to potential investors, co-founders Sergey Brin and Larry Page promised that the IPO would not change the company's culture. Later Mr. Page said, "We think a lot about how to maintain our culture and the fun elements."
==Criticism and controversy==
==Criticism and controversy==
Line 126: Line 126:
===The PageRank system===
===The PageRank system===
Google's central PageRank system has been criticized, some calling it "undemocratic". Common arguments are that the system is unfairly biased towards large web sites, and that the criteria for a page's importance are not subject to [[peer review]]. The system is also highly susceptible to manipulation and fraud through the use of dummy sites.
Google's central PageRank system has been criticized, some calling it "undemocratic". Common arguments are that the system is unfairly biased towards large web sites, and that the criteria for a page's importance are not subject to [[peer review]]. The system is also highly susceptible to manipulation and fraud through the use of dummy sites.
â   â
The system uses a series of characteristics to make it as effective as it is. Denoting when words are in bold case, or a larger font, when words are linked to, and what other sites(and how many of them) link to your site. The number of times a term is mentioned are also taken into account. This level of detail makes for far more accurate results, which gave Google a huge lead in terms of usefullness to the end-user when it first debuted. Since then, webmasters have learned to use these features against Google, linking to and repeatedly mentioning terms on a page to unfairly improve ranking in search results. Google has the policy of change early and often, thus, tweaks are made on a monthly basis sometimes, in an attempt to improve results and keep the frauds at bay.
